put something in the script that you can check like add "echo test > /test" or something tha is what I usually do
okay thanks
interesting, if i run the script from the terminal it works fine, but it hasnt fired for the past 3 days
root
the ones in /etc/cron.daily do at least
there is a user crontab that you can access with crontab -e
do the scripts in cron.daily execute sequentially or in parallel?
nothing executes in parallel technically
it executes through the command run-parts --report /etc/cron.daily
so man run-parts and see what exactly that means
turns out your cron - actuated scripts cannot have a "." in the name!
